reviewText: For years, I think Mad TV flew somewhat under the radar in the shadow of the more high profile and ever enduring SNL.  However, Mad TV and its crew of misfits seemed edgier and more madcap--willing to take risks, even if not everything paid off.  Aries Spears, on that show, showcased uncanny imitation abilities and an undeniable realness.  Nobody effectively skewers the contemporary urban vibe as viciously as Spears can.  So it's with pleasure to see him in his element in this Times Square concert where he edits himself to provide an extremely solid and balanced evening of comedy.  If you are an avid follower of Spears, not everything here will be brand new--but if you are new to his comic stylings, you're in for a fitful night of entertainment.As you might imagine, most of Spears set has to do with race relations in America.  Eschewing political correctness, Spears lays it all out gently poking at just about every ethnic group imaginable.  Race and gender differences have become such commonplace topics for comedians, it's getting harder and harder to make material that relies on stereotyping seem fresh.  However, the likable Spears acquits himself well with a monologue that is as truthful as it can be offensive!  And the audience loves it.For the second half of the show, he changes things up a bit.  There's a delightfully absurd send-up involving the movie Heat.  And for my money, it is Spears' impersonation of legendary comedy writer Paul Mooney that provides the night's most hysterical moments.  Even if you aren't familiar with Mooney (he worked with Pryor among others), this piece is brilliance and Spears' performance is priceless.  Capping things off is a terrifically demented music video!  Spears, as I said, uses some of his more popular material here and leaves out other stuff you might expect--but it is a well balanced show and a great introduction to Spears.  KGHarris, 4/11.
summary: The Emancipation Of Aries--Free From Mad TV To Be Explicitly Funny
